questions.question:
Question 1: Oxygen comes from alveoli to blood by  
.
questions.explanation:
Oxygen diffuses from alveoli to blood along the concentration gradient i.e. passive process (ATP is 
not used). 387 
Sold by @itachibot It diffuses across respiratory membrane It is governed by Fick’s law of diffusion which is given in equation: Where • D is the diffusion rate • P is the partial pressure difference between the two ends of the diffusion pathway • A is the cross-sectional area of the pathway • S is the solubility of the gas • d is the distance of diffusion • MW is the molecular weight of the gas. (Diffusion coefficient of the gas, which is proportional to S/MW ). 388 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: What is the time taken (in seconds) for blood to traverse the pulmonary capillaries at rest?
questions.explanation:
Time taken by a red cell is about 0.75 seconds to traverse the pulmonary capillaries at rest and 0.3 
seconds or less during exercise.

questions.question:
Question 3: What is the percentage of systemic cardiac output which bypasses the pulmonary circulation 
(physiological shunt)?
questions.explanation:
The percentage of cardiac output that bypasses the pulmonary circulation or physiological shunt is 
2%. The fraction of mixed venous blood that does not become oxygenated as it moves from the 
right atrium to the left ventricle is called physiologic shunt. Causes of physiological shunt: • Extrapulmonary R->L Anatomic Shunt (normally ~ 1% of cardiac output) • Intrapulmonary “True” Shunt • Flow past unventilated or collapsed alveoli (e.g., due to edema, pneumonia, atelectasis) • Anatomic arterio-venous pathways - Mixing of unoxygenated blood in bronchial veins with 
oxygenated blood in pulmonary capillaries or vein reduces the final partial pressure of O2 in the 
arterial blood (PaO2). • Intrapulmonary regions with low ventilation/perfusion ratio: Alveolar ventilation is not zero, but 
blood is not completely oxygenated (A virtual shunt, not a “true” shunt).

questions.question:
Question 4: A 35-year-old man with shortness of breath is undergoing tests to assess lung function. Which 
of the following is used to measure lung diffusion capacity?
questions.explanation:
The diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO) is measured as an index of the diffusing capacity of the 
lung because its uptake is diffusion-limited. The diffusing capacity of the lung for a given gas is directly proportional to the surface area of the 
alveolo-capillary membrane and inversely proportional to its thickness. 389 
Sold by @itachibot The normal value of DLCO at rest is about 25 mL/min/mm Hg. It increases up to threefold during exercise because of capillary dilation and an increase in the 
number of active capillaries.

questions.question: Question 5: The partial pressure of H2O at the body temperature (37° C) is (in mm Hg)
questions.explanation:
The partial pressure of water vapor at a normal body temperature of 37°C is ‡7 mm Hg. Humidification of air: • When dry air enters respiratory system it is humidified i.e. water molecules are continually 
escaping from the water surface (tissues) into the gas phase. • The partial pressure that the water molecules exert to escape through the surface is called the 
vapor pressure of the water. • The vapor pressure of water depends entirely on the temperature of the water. • The greater the temperature, the greater the kinetic activity of the molecules and, therefore, the 
greater the likelihood that the water molecules will escape from the surface of the water into the 
gas phase. • For instance, the water vapor pressure at 0°C is 5 mm Hg, and at 100°C it is 760 mm Hg. • The most important value to remember is the vapor pressure at body temperature ‡7 mm Hg. 
(Once the equilibrium is attained after diffusion, vapour pressure is called partial pressure). Alveolar A

questions.question: Question 6: What is the partial pressure of O2 in the alveolus?
questions.explanation: The partial pressure of O2 in the alveolus is 100 mmHg. The partial pressure of gases as they enter and leave the lungs is depicted below.

questions.question:
Question 7: If the tidal volume is 500 mL, PeCO2 is 30 mmHg and PaCO2 is ‡5 mmHg, calculate the 
dead space?
questions.explanation:
The Bohr-enghoff equation is used to calculate physiological dead space/total dead space. The original Bohr equation required measurement of the alveolar partial pressure of 
CO2 (PACO2). 391 
Sold by @itachibot Later Enghoff modified the equation and replaced the PACO2 with PaCO2 (partial pressure of 
CO2 in arterial blood). Enghoff's modification of Bohr equation is: Where, • VD is the physiological dead space • VT is the tidal volume • PaCO2 is the partial pressure of CO2 in the arterial blood • PeCO2 is the average partial pressure of CO2 in the entire expired air. Substituting the values: Vd=(‡5-30/‡5) x 500=166.66 ml 392 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is true regarding dead space volume in a healthy individual?

options.a: Anatomical dead space> physiologic dead space
options.b: Anatomical dead space< physiological dead space
options.c: Anatomical dead space and physiologic dead space are almost equivalent
options.d: Anatomical dead space is not related to physiologic dead space

questions.explanation:
In healthy individuals, anatomical dead space and physiologic dead space are almost equivalent, 
and can be estimated by body weight. Dead space is the volume of the airways and lungs that do not participate in gas exchange. Types • Anatomic dead space- Volume of the air-occupying conducting zone where no exchange of gases 
takes place. • Alveolar/functional dead space- the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood (wasted 
ventilation) • Total dead space/Physiological dead space = Anatomical + Alveolar dead space. In healthy individuals: • Anatomical dead space = 150 mL. • Alveolar dead space is usually zero (increased in diseased conditions). Hence, • Physiological dead space = Anatomical + Alveolar = 150 + 0 = 150 mL. • Physiological dead space = Anatomical dead space. • Radford's formula: Anatomical dead space in mL is approximately equal to the body weight in 
pounds. • Dead space can be measured by the following: • Single Breath N2 method (Fowler’s method) • Bohr’s equation

questions.question: Question 9: From base to the apex of the lung during standing, all the following decrease except

options.d: Intrapleural pressure (with respect to atmospheric pressure)

questions.explanation:
V/Q ratio does not decrease from the base to apex of the lung while standing. • Normal differences in ventilation and perfusion of the lung in the upright position (refer figure). Blood flow distribution in the lung PA: Alveolar pressure Pa: arterial pressure PV: venous pressure Pressure driving blood flow Zones of lung 
Blood fl 
ow Lowest 
PA> Pa> Pv Zone 1 (near Ape 
x) Zone 2 
Medium 
Pa> PA> Pv 393 
Sold by @itachibot Pressure driving blood flow Zones of lung 
Blood fl 
ow Zone 3 
Highest 
Pa> Pv> PA Ventilation–perfusion ratio is not the same in all part of the lungs because of the effect of gravity. At the apex (Against gravity): Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity. But, a decrease in 
perfusion is higher than the decrease in ventilation. Hence, ratio increases (3.2). At the base of lung: Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity. Increase in perfusion is 
more than increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, ratio decreases to 0.6. The average value of V/Q ratio throughout lungs is 0.8. Important points: • If the effect of gravity is eliminated, as in the supine position, the value is the same in all parts of 
the lung = 0.8. • V/Q ratio is infinity when perfusion is zero as in case of pulmonary embolism. • V/Q ratio is zero when ventilation is zero like in case of foreign body obstruction. • High V/Q ratio at apex leads to high pAO2 which favors the growth of microorganisms like 
tubercle bacilli. Intra-pleural pressure decreases as we move from the base to the apex of the lung i.e- becomes 
more negative as we move from the base to the apex of the lung.

questions.question: Question 10: Waterfall effect is seen in

options.a: Lower and middle portions of the lung

questions.explanation:
Water fall effect has been used to describe the blood flow in the middle portion of lung. 394 
Sold by @itachibot In this region blood flows in pulses. At first there is no flow because of obstruction at the 
collapsed venous end of the capillary bed. Pressure from the arterial side builds up until it exceeds 
alveolar pressure and flow resumes. This dissipates the capillary pressure and returns to the start 
of the cycle. The blood flow in this region is determined by the pulmonary artery–alveolar pressure difference. 
Blood “falls” into the pulmonary veins, which are compliant and take whatever amount of blood 
can flow into them. This has been called the waterfall effect. Blood flow distribution in the lung PA: Alveolar pressure Pa: arterial pressure PV: venous pressure Pressure driving blood flow Zones of lung 
Blood fl 
ow Lowest 
PA> Pa> Pv Zone 1 (near Ape 
x) Zone 2 
Medium 
Pa> PA> Pv Zone 3 
Highest 
Pa> Pv> PA

questions.question: Question 11: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions?

options.a: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
options.c: When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal
options.d: The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is ‡0 mmHg

questions.explanation:
VA /Q= infinity means that there is no exchange of O2 & CO2, which means the volume of 
the lung equals to dead space and the physiological effort of breathing is wasted. VA represents the ventilation in alveoli and Q represents the blood flow through the alveolus. The 
ratio of VA and Q explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar 
ventilation and alveolar blood flow. The ventilation-perfusion ratio is considered normal if there is 
an equal amount of blood flow & ventilation through the alveolus. VA /Q ratio is infinity when: • There is adequate ventilation but no perfusion. • No exchange of gases ( O2 and CO2 )through the respiratory membranes of corresponding 
alveoli. • The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air. • Partial pressures of the O2 and CO2 are 1‡9 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

questions.question:
Question 12: The O2-CO2 diagram shown below shows a ventilation-perfusion ratio curve for the normal 
lung. Which of the following options best describes the effect of decreasing the 
ventilation-perfusion ratio on the alveolar Po2 and Pco2? 385 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio implies decreased oxygenation due to decreased ventilation 
with respect to perfusion. Hence, PAO2 decreases and Pco2 increases. 395 
Sold by @itachibot A decrease in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (VA/Q) is depicted by moving to the left along the 
normal ventilation-perfusion line as shown in the figure (Zones here refer to the zones of variation 
in pulmonary blood flow and alveolar ventilation under influence of gravity) • Zone 1 - Zone 1 has the lowest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 3 but, in Zone 1 Ventilation 
(V)>>Perfusion (Q) hence V/Q is high • PAO2 is highest • PACO2 is lowest • Zone 2 - Ventilation (V) almost equal to Perfusion (Q) but slightly lower so V/Q is average (~0.8) • Zone 3 - Zone 3 has the highest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 1 but, in Zone 3 Perfusion 
(Q) >> Ventilation (V) hence V/Q is low • PAO2 is lowest • PACO2 is highest. *PAO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of oxygen *PACO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of CO2

questions.question:
Question 13: A person with normal lung at sea level (760 mm Hg) is breathing 50% oxygen. With a normal 
respiratory quotient of 0.8, what is the approximate alveolar Po2 (in mmHg)?
questions.explanation:
Alveolar gas equation is used to calculate partial pressure of O2 in alveolar air. It is given by the formula: 396 
Sold by @itachibot Where • PAO2 = Alveolar PO2 (mm Hg) • PIO2 = PO2 in inspired air (mm Hg) • PACO2 = Alveolar PCO2 (mm Hg), which is normally ‡0mmHg • R = Respiratory exchange ratio or respiratory quotient (CO2 production/O2 consumption) • Correction factor is usually negligible. Step 1: In the question PO2 in inspired air is not given directly. It has to be calculated using the 
formula: PIO2 = FIO2 (PB - PH20) Where • PIO2 = PO2 in inspired air (mm Hg) • FIO2 = Fraction of inspired O2 (50% or 0.5) • PB = Barometric pressure (760 mmHg) • PH2O = Water vapour pressure (‡7 mmHg) Substituting the values: PIO2 = 0.5 (760 - ‡7) = 0.5 × 713 = 356.5 mmHg Step 2: PAO2 = PiO2 – (Pco2/R) = 356.5 – (‡0/0.8) = 356.5 – 50 = 306.5 mmHg.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following decreases in a patient with emphysema?
questions.explanation:
In emphysema, the destruction of the alveolar walls brings down the diffusion area. 397 
Sold by @itachibot Changes in Emphysema • Due to the destruction of the alveolar walls, there is a decrease in surface/diffusion area. • Cardiac output will be normal. • Pulmonary artery pressure may be elevated because the destruction of alveoli leads to loss of 
surrounding capillaries which forces blood into remaining capillaries, which tends to increase 
pulmonary artery pressure. • Alveolar Pco2 will tend to increase due to difficulty in expiration. Diffusion capacity of Lung for CO (DLCO): • In case of emphysema – Decreased diffusion (DLCO) because of decreased surface area (trypsin 
destroys respiratory membrane) • In case of fibrosis or pulmonary edema – Decreased diffusion (DLCO) because of increased 
thickness of membrane • In case of anemia – Decreased DLCO • Polycythemia, pulmonary hemorrhage – Increased DLCO.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following best describes the mean arterial oxygen tension (pO2), carbon dioxide 
tension (pCO2) and pH in a healthy athlete during moderate exercise?
questions.explanation:
During moderate exercise, there is no change in arterial pO2, arterial pCO2 or arterial pH. Ventilation increases abruptly at the onset of exercise due to psychic stimuli and afferent impulses 
from proprioceptors in muscles, tendons, and joints. This is followed by a brief pause and then a 
gradual increase in ventilation. This gradual increase in ventilation is believed to be due to 
multiple factors such as an increase in body temperature, increase in plasma K+ level stimulating 
peripheral chemoreceptors, or the sensitivity of the neurons controlling the response to CO2. In strenuous exercise, at a certain point, the O2 uptake reaches its maximum levels, beyond which 
it cannot increase further. This leads to a rise in blood lactate levels. Buffering of lactic acid 
liberates CO2 which further increases ventilation. The increased production of lactic acid, increase 
in ventilation and CO2 production are proportional, and alveolar and arterial CO2 changes little to 
nil. This is called isocapnic buffering. 398 
Sold by @itachibot Gas Transport in Blood
